answers.a: A function that describes the shape of an electron's location.
answers.b: A function that gives the probability of finding the particle.
answers.c: A function that describes the energy levels of an atom.
answers.d: A function that gives the velocity of a particle.

explanations.a: No, Can we know exact location of the electron??

questions.question: 3. Which of the following describes a finite potential well?

questions.question: 4. Calculate the probability of finding a particle in a specific region within an infinite potential well if the wave function is given by \( \psi(x) = \sqrt{\frac{2}{L}} \sin\left(\frac{n\pi x}{L}\right) \). Assume \( n = 1 \) and \( L = 1 \).

explanations.a: True, particle has to exist within the given limits

questions.question: 5. In a system which is invert of 1D finite potential well (i.e. system potential barrier V(x) exists, between x=0 and x=L and particle is free in d: 0.25 all other regions (x<0 and x>L). If particle is located in x<0 and moving towards x=0, what will be characteristics of SWE solution (wavefunction) is the barrier and in the free space?

answers.a: Particle has a sinusoidal wave function every where
answers.b: Particle has a decaying wave function everywhere
answers.c: Particle cannot exist in this system
answers.d: Particle wavefunction is sinusoidal in x<=0 and x>=L and decays exponentially 0<x<L

explanations.a: When E<V(x), solution is not sinusoidal
explanations.b: Wave function cannot be decaying in free space
explanations.d: Yes, this is called tunneling. particle is found on other side of the barrier with lower probability.

questions.question: 6. For above system, which of the following will be true?

answers.a: Particle wave function should be zero for x>= L
answers.b: Particle wave function amplitude will increase for x>=L
answers.c: Particle will bounce back completely at x=0
answers.d: Larger the value of L, lower is the amplitude of wavfunction for x>=L

explanations.c: No, paritcle won’t bounce back with 100% probability.
explanations.d: Yes, wider barrier L implies more decay in the barrier.
